args.justification: The original 'AI System Stakeholders' class conflates two distinct stakeholder roles—those merely affected by AI decisions and those who design or operate AI systems—so splitting improves conceptual clarity and downstream use.

args.new_description: Formal legal and rule-based frameworks that govern the development, deployment, and use of AI technologies, including compliance obligations and enforcement mechanisms.
args.justification: This class clearly represents legal governance instruments around AI, so assigning it to a broader 'AI Governance and Stakeholders' group connects it with related stakeholder classes.

args.new_description: Persons whose lives, rights, or opportunities may be affected by AI system decisions, without necessarily designing or operating the systems.
args.justification: The affected-individuals split is a stakeholder type within the same AI governance ecosystem, so it should share the 'AI Governance and Stakeholders' group with AI regulations and operator stakeholders.

args.new_description: People or organizations that design, build, deploy, or directly operate AI systems (e.g., developers and users).
args.justification: Developers and users are institutional stakeholders within the AI governance landscape, so assigning the same 'AI Governance and Stakeholders' group maintains a coherent upper-level schema.

args.new_description: Defensive behavioral adaptations in which caterpillars visually blend into their environment, including general background matching and specific mimicry of plant parts such as twigs and leaves.

args.new_description: Taxonomic species of caterpillars (larval lepidopterans), used to explain variation in larval traits such as body shape, size, and color.
args.justification: This class represents the taxonomic basis for variation in caterpillar traits and is closely related to defensive strategies, so aligning it under the same 'Caterpillar Biology and Defense' group connects morphology and behavior within one biological domain.

args.justification: All three classes cover the same high-level concept of how AI affects society and the economy (benefits, risks, and broader implications), with strongly overlapping scopes and entities (productivity, efficiency, inequality, concentration of power, societal impact, potential of AI), so they should form a single unified class rather than three near-duplicate ones.
The merged class represents overall societal and economic impacts of AI and should be grouped with AI harms and risks under a shared higher-level Class_Group describing AI impacts and harms.

Discriminatory Treatment captures unjust outcomes/events closely tied to algorithmic bias and protected characteristics, so it should share the same AI Fairness, Bias & Data class group.

Protected Characteristics (race, gender) are core concepts in discrimination and fairness discussions and should be grouped with algorithmic bias and discriminatory treatment under AI Fairness, Bias & Data.
AI Training Data, including biased and incomplete subsets, is a primary source of algorithmic bias and discriminatory outcomes, so it belongs in the same AI Fairness, Bias & Data group.

Problematic Training Data (biased/incomplete) is explicitly described as leading to discriminatory outcomes, tightly coupling it to fairness/bias mechanisms and warranting the AI Fairness, Bias & Data group.

Massive Data Assets are large-scale datasets used by AI systems; although they also raise privacy concerns, in this cluster they relate to data governance feeding into fairness and bias, so they fit the AI Fairness, Bias & Data group.

Training data and massive amounts of data are both foundational AI datasets; introducing an AI Data Assets class provides a coherent parent structure above more specific classes (AI Training Data, Massive Data Assets) without disturbing their existing roles.

The new AI Data Assets class organizes core datasets relevant to fairness and bias, so it should share the same AI Fairness, Bias & Data class group as the other data- and discrimination-related classes.

args.justification: ClsC_5a5ed473 currently mixes an anatomical structure entity (butterfly wings) with a transient physiological state (soft, wrinkled wings), so it should be split into separate anatomy vs state classes for cleaner semantics.

args.new_description: Anatomical wing structures of butterflies, focusing on the mature, flight-enabling appendages as part of adult anatomy.
args.new_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States
args.justification: After moving the transient wing-state entity out, ClsC_5a5ed473 now cleanly represents the anatomical structure and should be renamed and clarified while retaining the existing class_group.

args.new_description: Transient early post-emergence states of butterfly wings (soft, wrinkled, not yet fully expanded or hardened) prior to functional flight.
args.new_class_group: Butterfly Metamorphosis, Anatomy, and Experiential States
args.justification: The new split class should be explicitly modeled as a physiological state within the same metamorphosis/anatomy/experiential class_group for consistent upper-level organization.

cluster_classes.class_description: Organizational procedures and workflows used to evaluate, screen, and select job applicants, including both human and algorithmic decision steps.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Organizational procedures and workflows used to evaluate and select job applicants.

members.entity_description: Organizational procedures and workflows used to evaluate and select job applicants.

cluster_classes.class_description: Processes by which choices or judgments are made, including those supported or automated by AI, with attention to fairness and bias.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: choices or judgments are made, often supported or automated by AI; fairness and equity in decision-making

members.entity_description: Processes by which choices or judgments are made, often supported or automated by AI.

args.justification: Hiring processes are a specific form of organizational decision-making about applicants, so they should share a common upper-level Class_Group with general decision-making processes while remaining a distinct class.
General decision-making processes provide the broader context into which hiring processes fit, so assigning the same Class_Group connects these related but non-duplicate classes in the schema.
